snippet.textDisplay: Taiwan simply gave up. Just like Europe and America did long time ago. Let's not beautify giving up as victory.

snippet.textDisplay: @梁浩LiangHao You're acting like china doesn't basically have rebranded capitalism. You can have that without democracy.
snippet.textOriginal: @梁浩LiangHao You're acting like china doesn't basically have rebranded capitalism. You can have that without democracy.

snippet.textDisplay:
@梁浩LiangHao You keep comparing and then dragging off to other systems.  While never acknowledging the current or future climate. I am talking of choice and your own beliefs.   Where you are talking about trivial things like swearing and what other countries are doing as is your method to veer off and solidify your argument without looking deep into the ruling party.  

Also you failed to even answer anyone of the questions i posed above.  There is a lot of things wrong with the west of course. 

What “choices” of parties can one be promoted in?  Where can you choose to join which party you want to join? Why ONLY them? Who said so? Them? 

Who is in power now? Isnt he a descendant? As been the ones previous to him and so on and on.  If the chinese citizen as a collective whole dont like him can they choose another? Or ones after that? Is this best party? Why isn’t there others that better? Why is all choice cut off? Who decided that? The citizens?  What if there could be a one party thats better then? Is that possible? 
Can your children have any realistic hope of deciding for themselves if they want to join another party or become the leader of this ruling party?

snippet.textDisplay: @Alfie  You still have no idea what performance is.  In China, if you want to be promoted, you need to beat your competitors in economy and many other aspects. This is the governance of the real world. But under the voting system, what you need to do is swear worse than your competitors, arouse more hatred, and make more unsubstantiated accusations，Basically by talk them to death😂.

snippet.textDisplay:
@梁浩LiangHao 
The differences between a company and country is so stark and you in saying that helped clearly demonstrate why there is a need for choice. When it comes to our leaders
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: @Alfie You have election, and you have one million homeless too. In China, If a guy becomes the president, which means that all the way to here，the regions he was responsible for have the fastest in economic growth, the best in environmental protection, the lowest in unemployment rate and the most satisfying in polls among competitors. There were thousands of choices in this competition process, he had thousands of competitors, if not hundreds of thousands.and the best choice has been made in the results of the laws of the universe，which is performance. But in a Voting System How do you beat your 5~20 competitors? Through media promotion to decide the outcome，with some cheap talking maybe.
snippet.textOriginal: @Alfie You have election, and you have one million homeless too. In China, If a guy becomes the president, which means that all the way to here，the regions he was responsible for have the fastest in economic growth, the best in environmental protection, the lowest in unemployment rate and the most satisfying in polls among competitors. There were thousands of choices in this competition process, he had thousands of competitors, if not hundreds of thousands.and the best choice has been made in the results of the laws of the universe，which is performance. But in a Voting System How do you beat your 5~20 competitors? Through media promotion to decide the outcome，with some cheap talking maybe.

snippet.textDisplay:
@梁浩LiangHao first of all a country is own by the “people” which can be life and death by their decisions?  From taxes, jail, jobs, schools, roads, transport, health and so on. 

a company is for profit by making products and services and they can choose their own leaders if the company fails people lose their jobs and then people can “choose” other jobs.  

you are BORN into a country and you are identified as chinese, if you were to ask to leave your country why is it more theirs than yours? No one owns it.  If there is no voting its fine.  The voting system should apply to countries. 

In a country if the leaders fail and people did not choose them they have no where else to go.  The country always serves the people not the other way around.

Big difference between the two.

But there you go again sliding to other comparisons which is not relevant in this case tho…. I hope you can consider that.

snippet.textDisplay:
@梁浩LiangHao the issue here is, its a one ruling party state.  Do you have a choice in who you choose? Say this guy now is terrific president! How about the next one or the next? 

What if they are terrible do you get to choose to kick him out or not? 

What if you dont want this party to be in power?  Its not whether you decide to join this party, and you rise through the ranks.  Its you have NO other choice but to join it if you want to be in politics.

Then who choose these specific people to be in power? The people of china? Or themselves?  What if you don’t like this party one day? 

If you and i decide one day to speak out against it, is there NO penalty to say so? 

These are questions i think you should angle yourself towards rather than making comparisons to the west to avoid the entirety of the questions, which they ALSO have their flaws.  But it does nothing but run in circles.

snippet.textDisplay: @Alfie Why don't Apple, Google and IBM elect their CEO by one person one vote? Since vote is so advanced. According to your theory, these companies should abandon their political system based on achievements, but rely on votes to decide the choice of executives. Guess how long it will take for them to go bankrupt? Moreover, why can their positions avoid hereditary? This means that one person one vote is far more primitive and backward than the way the company operates.
snippet.textOriginal: @Alfie Why don't Apple, Google and IBM elect their CEO by one person one vote? Since vote is so advanced. This means that one person one vote is far more primitive and backward than the way the company operates.

snippet.textDisplay: @Alfie It's very simple. They are responsible for economic growth figures, environmental improvement figures, employment rate, unemployment rate, new ventures, polls, technology patents, and so on. Many standards are easy to quantify, and at least twice a year, all officials will be assessed for their performance, so as to determine their fate. According to what you said, I wonder why companies such as Apple, Google and IBM do not operate through a democratic system, but through "dictatorship".

@梁浩LiangHao  so your answer is better than 100% then quickly deflect on the west? I dont care about the west.  Why are you bringing them up?  

we are talking about the ruling party right? its not as free and easy to be in top position as you are painting it to be.

Who exactly elected them? The people? Or a person? 

So the top seed is 100% right? He must have got that position through hard work and his achievements and nothing with sway from his descendants.

snippet.textDisplay: @Alfie There are only five members of China's highest standing committee, including Xi Jinping. 25 people refer to the total number since the founding of the People's Republic of China.
snippet.textOriginal: @Alfie There are only five members of China's highest standing committee, including Xi Jinping. 25 people refer to the total number since the founding of the People's Republic of China.

snippet.textDisplay:
@梁浩LiangHao its interesting you choose to segment your number in 25, what about the top 60 or 100? Whats the percentile? 

Also, for the top 25 is handpicked by xi and why would he choose any princeling that would get in his way?   So understand the distorted numbers and deep politics involved.  Princelings are rampant across the party and its not as clear cut as you believe by rising through the ranks.  It’s ridiculous if you believe its through “only their achievements” as you can find they are all related somehow to someone with ties to the founding party.
